snippet.textDisplay:
To all who think that Jesus hates homosexuals, would you please site any red letter scripture confirming that claim?
What?...Nothing?

I wonder why that is?

Here is some red letter scripture for you:

““Woe to you, teachers of the law and Pharisees, you hypocrites! You shut the door of the kingdom of heaven in people’s faces. You yourselves do not enter, nor will you let those enter who are trying to.

“Woe to you, teachers of the law and Pharisees, you hypocrites! You travel over land and sea to win a single convert, and when you have succeeded, you make them twice as much a child of hell as you are...
…“Woe to you, teachers of the law and Pharisees, you hypocrites! You build tombs for the prophets and decorate the graves of the righteous. And you say, ‘If we had lived in the days of our ancestors, we would not have taken part with them in shedding the blood of the prophets.’ So you testify against yourselves that you are the descendants of those who murdered the prophets. Go ahead, then, and complete what your ancestors started! “You snakes! You brood of vipers! How will you escape being condemned to hell?”
‭‭Matthew‬ ‭23

snippet.textDisplay: The statement you made of Jehova's witnesses holding themselves above the law is very true. Military service is obligatory in Finland for men who have turned 18. Jehova's witnesses are the only people who are allowed to not complete the obligatory military service because of their religion. All other Finnish men who are capable, no matter if they're Muslim, Christian or Jew, have to complete the military service or do a year of civil service. If they won't do it they'll end up in jail. The witnesses have been able to avoid it for years and no one questions it. They don't even have to do civil service and are freed of everything. No jail time, no nothing.

snippet.textDisplay:
There is a GORGEOUS photographer named Shelbie Dimond on Instagram who is 3rd generation Witness. Her father disowned her in front of the elders when she was 14 and she became an apostate. Her parents, friends, extended family, entire community have rejected her, and have taken to reporting her images on multiple Instagram accounts (I'm talking shadowbanned for YEARS on MULTIPLE accounts with 20K+ followers), resulting in her losing income, jobs, and homes/living situations. She has suffered immensely at the hands of this cult, and in the five years that I've followed her journey I've never felt more helpless or sad for an artist. There are countless people all over the world that are harassed, bullied, manipulated by their own family members for YEARS after they walk away from the organization. This is not a religion. This is dangerous.

Thank you for brining light to a tragic situation, Hannah, for voicing your truth and thereby elevating the voices of others who haven't been heard. You are so loved, radically and unapologetically. My heart is with you as you navigate this heartbreak, and I hope you know that there is endless grace for the journey you've been on and will continue down with your partner Ella. I love you. Thank you for speaking Truth. <3

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm so proud of you for facing and trying to overcome the pains you are facing in your life.
My grandfather is a Jehovah's Witness as well and there are stories that I can't begin to describe how distressing, disgusting they were.
He is a kind and pleasant man, but what he follows is full of spite.
I don't know if he's aware of my relationships (whether that's with a man, a woman, or someone else on the spectrum of gender) or religious views, etc... I don't want to know.
I have felt the pain of rejection from other family members and friends for parts of me that I can't have any control over. And it's not my fault that those people can't be open or caring enough to try and understand.
It is not your fault either.
I wish you all the love and care and support that you need. It's never easy, but having a community to support and love you makes a difference. That's something that you have provided to so many people and I hope that they are able to find those things as well.
Live your truth, so you can learn to love and accept yourself.

snippet.textDisplay: You are correct: you have nothing to be ashamed of. A parent’s love ought to be wholly unconditional and I am grieving with you for the pain it causes to be denied that. You are an incredible human, and he is bereft for not being able to set aside his own insecurities to embrace you. But that doesn’t mean it doesn’t hurt like hell. Enjoy your wedding and the love that surrounds you and your fiancée both as you celebrate together. Mourn what you need to, but I hope you will never forget that you are already, and always have been, enough precisely as you are, and it is his failing for not being able to recognize that.

snippet.textDisplay: The thing about abusive people or groups is that they have this power over you that you can’t expose them for fear of be it backfiring, or even you might feeling guilty. But that’s when you eat up and store up all the pain and suffering and it makes you not grow in life and worse fall into some horrible mental illnesses. snippet.textDisplay:
Thank you so much for sharing Hannah. Your story, experience, and emotions in response to your dad's rejection resonate strongly with me. I am a gay male who grew up in and deeply conservative and close-minded Christian community. For those that are curious, the church I grew up in is Calvinist in denomination. My father also rejects my identity, despite saying he loves me. I had thought I didn't care anymore and had just accepted that my relationship with my father would be a privilege I am not destined to enjoy, but without even knowing why, I became extremely depressed and the tears and pain were very real both mentally and physically. It's a strange phenomena. Deep down, I think a majority of us still do care. It is especially soul-crushing to see one's parent/s choose their belief system above their child. But I didn't start this comment to give my life story. I wanted to thank you for posting this but also comment on how relatable your emotional experience is. While it is devastating to see the hurt you are going through, it is strengthening to know that so many of us in our community experience similar experiences. There is a power in numbers, and just seeing, hearing, and feeling others that we can relate to give us strength. Not a fighting strength, but a will-power. The will to live life and embracing the right to be happy just as any other human being deserves.


I have watched you since the old days of Youtube. You know, before the word "Youtuber" was even a thing :) I have watched and rewatched so many of your videos and was a big fan of the Holy Trinity of Youtube, hehe. I treasure those days and those experiences. You being gay and representing gave me a glimpse of a potential future, and a peak into something like hope for me. I only recently came out. It took so much time and so much courage to finally take that first step. As I am learning to adapt to this new transition in my life, I fondly recall the brave individuals who came out on Youtube. Your sweet, genuine, and honest projection of self combined with being gay has had a huge impact on me who was a closeted and scared boy stuck in a sick cycle of cult-like environment coupled with the brainwashed ideas that I couldn't get out of my head. I still struggle to declare the right to be happy on even a fundamental level, and that is the devastatingly deep reach of many religions that invade and destroy our souls. But I keep telling myself what other supporting loved ones tell me: it will get better. I just wanted to send you my love and condolences on what you are going through, but also take this moment to thank you for being you all these years and moving forward in pursuing a happy life and a BEAUTIFUL partner with whom you will share it. I know I am not alone when I say this. We appreciate, love, and celebrate you!!!

snippet.textDisplay:
Hannah it's almost hard to believe I've watched you for...7 years I want to say. Before you settled into a hairstyle and your drunk kitchens were, well, super drunk. We are about the same age and I kinda feel like I grew up with you. Because we never stop growing and our 20s is an especially identifying time. To hear this heartbreak in your voice is an honest pang in my soul. I dont know you but I kinda do, in the way we know anyone we care about.

Knowing he made that choice, that it is in no way your fault and that you do deserve to be happy...it doesnt change it. We will always love our parents even when they are wrong (and he is so, so wrong). I'm not going to give you any advice or tell you to cheer up because let's all be honest that is some bs. So I'm going to tell you what a wonderful person told me a few years ago when I lost the most important person in my life: be sad. Go ahead and cry, be upset and be angry if you want. Feel everything that's inside and dont hold it back. Because when you hold it back you can never truly let that pain go. If you keep it inside that's where it will always be.

You dont know me at all. But I'm proud of you, Hannah.

snippet.textDisplay:
The Jehovah's Witnesses came to our door many times in 2019.
And being Christian, we wanted to listen to their story,
and hear their beliefs, and to know why they felt we should be a part of their organization,
even though we are already following Christ's teaching, and already saved.
And when ever the discussion would turn to Bible scripture,
they would refer to their own dogma instead from pamphlets they carry.
Their dogma often has scripture references in parenthesis,
and we were happy to get out our King James Bible and read those verses aloud,
but...
They never felt comfortable when we did.
And the King James Bible verses, did NOT always agree with their dogma.
And when it did not, they would move on to another subject, or repeat a well-rehearsed line
about how much they would love to have us come into the "new light" with them.
That was their fall-back position on why the King James Bible did not always agree...
because that was "old wisdom" but the Witnesses now have "new light".

So literally, they were telling us, the Bible is secondary for them,
and you have to set its teaching aside when it does not agree with Jehovah's Witness dogma.
You must accept their dogma OVER the teaching of the Bible.
And we knew then that they were not actually following Christ's teaching.
And they were NOT filled with light, new, old or otherwise,
they were filled with political dogma, written by people who have a philosophy
and who try to conceal that political philosophy with facade of Christianity.

They stopped coming back when we told them sorry, but we will keep following Jesus instead, thank you.

snippet.textDisplay: I have an understanding of a parent, community and etc.  not approving of my "lifestyle". My mom, although not religious, she did not accept me until I was 23 and i came out officially to her when I was in high school.  My family has avoided the conversation completely. My dad still hasn't accepted me and is in denial and his side does not talk to me. I love my mom and step dad and how open and comfortable I am with them. She told me she loves me and that she respects my decision and says there is much more to be afraid of and worry about in this world but knowing you and your decisions you will be ok and that's all that matters. It hurts and you feel like your falling but at the same time someone or something has grabbed you to pull you back up. Stay strong Hannah. I live in a small Texas town that exiled me, bit when I ventured I found people that I consider family that have celebrated and mourned with me more than anyone else. You have Ella and sometimes that one person can be that hand that stops you from falling. That organization will wrong them and they will too be free.

snippet.textDisplay: Just because someone is your family doesn't mean you have to be okay with them hurting you. It's okay to not be okay. This is a tough one. I recently watched my grandmother not attend my mother's wedding and how hurt my mother was. It is a lot to not be put first, especially when it's a parents job to be there for their child in good or bad times. It's also their job to accept them for who they are and love them unconditionally. It's sad to see a parent chose to leave their duties of a parent behind for something that really doesn't mean as much as their children do. And I say that as a very religious person, a person means more than any word in religion. I hope you can heal from this and continue on living your happy loving and soon to be married life 💕

snippet.textDisplay:
I've watched and thoroughly loved your videos for a few years now and I never thought to relate to closely to you in such an awful way.
I'll be honest, it took me years to heal and I don't know if it will ever be over, but we've been married for 19 wonderful years this July.
I don't know if you read the comments, especially when there are this many, but in case you see this;
You are wonderful, your love is beautiful, and your father not choosing you is no reflection on you and a loss for him. And thank you for sharing, you make a difference. Silence is not easy to break when it's your life, your family, and the consequences are so deeply felt.

Thank you, thank you, thank you.

Again, I am sending you and Ella both so much love. We love you.

My father died when I was 16. So I grew up knowing he would only be at my special events in spirit. He was a conservative catholic from a typical Irish American family. But we always knew that he would support us no matter what. I have felt his spirit at every special event my siblings and I have had throughout our lives.

And although I did not grow up to be catholic and pray routinely, I do believe our loved ones can hear us in the beyond. I will ask my dad to send his fatherly love and energy to you and Ella on your wedding day.

He firmly believe that love should always be celebrated. So while it can not replace or fix the hurt caused by your dad, just know that you will have a dad smiling down on you both.

snippet.textDisplay: My parents, who are ultra Catholic, almost didn't come to my wedding. My dad wouldn't walk me down the aisle (my brother did), though he still wanted to do a father- daughter dance with me. My mother was probably more uncomfortable than my dad and she had the nerve to pull my wife aside during the wedding and basically told her how she still wasn't okay with it. Sometimes parents suck and it hurts. If they hadn't come I probably would have dropped our relationship. I'm glad they came so our kids can know them, but it wasn't easy. We're fortunate that my wife's parents have been so loving and supportive which helps a lot! There are people who love you no matter what. Cling to them and stay strong! 💗💜

There are so many comments i feel like mine will get lost in the sea but thats okay.
Going into this video i didn't know what to expect. I kinda assumed it was something like your father not accepting you but i had no idea that i would come out of it crying. I'm going through something really similar right now. My mother is a Witness and i only finally came out to her about 2 years ago now. I no longer have the relationship i had with my mom anymore. She was my best friend growing up and we just understood eachother so well. It breaks my heart that this is what makes our relationship die. It hurts me so bad to know you're going through something so similar Hannah, but theres also a sense of warmth knowing theres someone who knows exactly how i feel. I have this beautiful girl in my life and it's constantly weighed down by the fact that my mom doesn't approve and i'm still partially reliant on her due to life situations. I'm just happy my father has nothing to do with it and he's always been incredibly supportive about this, maybe a little dated with his jokes but loves me no matter what.
I really felt it and understood so heavily when you were talking about the unconditional love thing, i've been thinking for years about how my love to others is so unconditional and i always thought i got that back from my mother but ever since coming out i've realized thats not the case and it's a feeling that is impossible to describe. I understand you, i see you, and i am here. I hope you have the best fucking wedding ever and just know you are living a beautiful life and i know you know this, but just as a reminder, the person you choose to love isn't wrong, its beautiful and you're both so beautiful and i'm kinda just ranting here at this point cause this video hit way too close to home.
I am sending so much love and warmth to you and Ella right now, and i hope you just know you're not alone in this feeling.
Lots of love <3

snippet.textDisplay:
Hannah, you have every right to be upset. Not having someone you love at your wedding is horrible no matter the circumstances. That being said, you have every right to celebrate who you are and all the people who love you in every way you want. If anyone in this world chooses to not celebrate the amazing person that you are, they are making a mistake. As much as that mistake hurts, and it's hard to process how it hurts you, it's not your fault that others cannot choose to embrace you.

Take your time to process this in a healthy way, and remember that for every one person who brings you down, there is hundreds of others who are here to lift you back up. 🌈💖

snippet.textDisplay:
There is so much...so much I want to say to you. As a fan who used to watch MDK back in the day and tunes into your amazing channel from time to time, I know how amazing of a person you are. And...listen I know this is probably going to be lost in a sea of good vibes and well wishes, but you have such a beautiful and amazing soul. My wife and I love you and you put so much positive into the world. But I know that the pain you feel is a burden that follows you though all the positivity and love you push out. It's hard. And I'm sorry you have to suffer like this. I wish our parents would understand that their burdens should never be placed on their children. That their beliefs never hinder or hold back their own family's growth. And I wished more than anything that you or anyone else didnt have to go through this for any reason. Our parents should always be the ones who stand the tallest on our side for whatever reason and...to feel abandoned by them is...

Hannah, I'm going to be a new parent soon, in September. And if I've been taught anything by your experience, or my own, or any of my friends...it's that my child will always and forever be my only priority. And I hope one day, no matter how unlikely it may be, that your father adopts that viewpoint as well. I wish you and your wife the best life you can possibly have.

snippet.textDisplay: It seems people think our lifestyle is still a CHOICE.  Reality and science says it's NOT a choice.  WE didn't have a choice when we were born.  Family members CHOOSE to ignore, isolate, shun, disown and remove from their lives all these wonderful people who didn't have a choice when they were born.  Human instinct is to get rid of or kill off things they don't understand.  I also come from a religious family (all baptists), I came out to my folks some 25 years ago.  They didn't talk to me for a year.  However, they came to the realization that they would rather have their son than be cut off from him.  However, my lifestyle is something we don't talk about (out of sight, out of mind).  Fast forward 25 years, I am disabled and forced to move back in with my folks.  I had to throw away pretty much my entire life of mementos and other items that were important to my lifestyle all because they didn't wanna see it.  my mother went as far as cutting up portraits and drawings from at artist friend of mine just so my dad wouldn't see it.  Again, it is their CHOICE.  My choices were taken away from me the day I ended up in a wheelchair.  I just want you and Ella to be happy.  I have watched you for years and I am sorry you are going through this.  I'm sure it would pretty much go the same way for me if I ever got married.  Sending you much love and positive vibes!!!!!!  <3

snippet.textDisplay: I struggle with this feeling a lot Hannah. I'm 31, marrying my partner of 10 years this September, and I constantly have questions about why I care so much about how my parents react to my sexuality. I've even come to a place now after therapy and trying everything, every way of thinking, that I can somewhat separate the lovable faulted imperfect parts of them from the parts that don't approve of my life. It's the most difficult kind of love there is to give though, in my opinion, and it leaves me feeling weary and empty a lot of the time. I know you don't need your feelings justified because you're a solid person and you're making a beautiful life for yourself, but I hear you and feel you. Sending all the good vibes!

snippet.textDisplay: thank you for that video even if it hurt. /hug/ it helps to know you're not alone in being rejected by a parent, even though it feels a bit like flailing around wildly not knowing what to do or why this is happening (of course we know logically, but emotionally that's what it feels like to me). it's not fair. it really isn't. to anyone in similar hurt (even if different situations), what's helped/still helps me is "Adult Children of Emotionally Immature Parents : How to Heal from Distant, Rejecting, or Self-Involved Parents" by Lindsay Gibson and her sequel "Recovering of Emotionally Immature Parents".

snippet.textDisplay: it is a horrible cult, i absolutely know what you mean. (For me it was not a wedding but a funeral of a beloved family member). Of course, that's not your fault and of course that still hurts. Choosing a "religion" over such an important day is a very sad life choice. However, people like your father are victims too. At a certain point in life, they have lost their footing and they were in desperate need of some carrying community. what they got is an institution that only wanted their money and free work. it's horrible. Wishing you the best marriage ever and wishing your dad, even if the chances are small, that one day he's able to leave this toxic cult behind.
